election_record.label: Massachusetts 1818 Lieutenant Governor

overview.note: There was considerable controversy over whether those citizens living on plantations in what is now the state of Maine should be allowed to vote in state elections. They did not pay taxes and many thought they should thus not be allowed to vote. Beginning in 1814, in many of the plantations, the votes were cast and counted and included separately in the Original Election Returns, with their totals not included among the aggregate state totals.

sub_unit.name: Otis
sub_unit.note: "No return." Original Election Returns.

sub_unit.name: Richmond
sub_unit.note: "Return not signed by Town Clerk." Original Election Returns.

sub_unit.name: Southfield
sub_unit.note: "Informal." Original Election Returns.

sub_unit.name: Washington
sub_unit.note: Benjamin W. Crowninshield received 1 vote as Benjamin Crowninshield.

sub_unit.note: Thomas Kittredge received 4 votes as Thomas Wittredge.

sub_unit.note: Thomas Kittredge received 5 votes as Ebenezer Kittredge.

sub_unit.note: "No return." Original Election Returns.

sub_unit.note: "Return not certified by Town Clerk." Original Election Returns.
